extractions.title: Investigating the Shared Genetic Architecture Between Kidney Function and Alzheimer's Disease Across Ancestries

extractions.trait: Alzheimer's disease (AD) — local (European ancestry)
extractions.method_detail: LAVA (local heritability / local genetic correlation analysis using GWAS summary statistics). Study also used LDSC for genome-wide analyses and cond/conjFDR for pleiotropy detection.
extractions.source_text: In EUR, 52 regions showed significant local correlations (Bonferroni‐corrected), and heritability (AD: h² = 0.05, p ≈ 0.025; eGFR: h² = 0.10, p < 1E‐10).
extractions.evidence_html: ...ificant (r g values ≈ 0.07) in both ancestries, with regions of strong local correlations observed. In EUR, 52 regions showed significant local correlations (Bonferroni‐corrected), and heritability (AD: h² = 0.05, p ≈ 0.025; eGFR: h² = 0.10, p < 1E‐10). These regions exhibited balanced bidirectional correlations (26 loci each; positive range: 0.32 to ...

extractions.title: Integrated genetic analysis of Alzheimer's disease and stroke subtypes: insights from LDSC, PLACO, and MR studies.

extractions.trait: Alzheimer's disease
extractions.method_detail: Value cited in the paper from prior literature (references [41,42] in the manuscript). The paper does not specify which estimation method produced this 24% value within this text.
extractions.ancestry: European (inferred; authors used 1000 Genomes European LD scores as reference)
extractions.source_text: Complex diseases like AD and IS are largely influenced by the collective impact of numerous common genetic variants, with each variant contributing a minor portion of the overall risk [ 40 ], it is es
extractions.evidence_html: ...mber of variants ( HDAC9 ) affecting the specific stroke subtypes have been identified [ 38 , 39 ]. Complex diseases like AD and IS are largely influenced by the collective impact of numerous common genetic variants, with each variant contributing a minor portion of the overall risk [ 40 ], it is estimated that these common genetic variants account for about 24% of the variance in AD and about 18% in stroke [ 41 , 42 ]. extractions.method_detail: Value cited in the paper from prior literature (references [41,42] in the manuscript). The paper does not specify which estimation method produced this 18% value within this text.

Complex diseases like AD and IS are largely influenced by the collective impact of numerous common genetic variants, with each variant contributing a minor portion of the overall risk [ 40 ], it is estimated that these common genetic variants account for about 24% of the variance in AD and about 18% in stroke [ 41 , 42 ]. extractions.title: Alzheimer disease is (sometimes) highly heritable: Drivers of variation in heritability estimates for binary traits, a systematic review.

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD)
extractions.method_detail: Lee et al. (2013) GCTA/GREML estimate based on individual-level data
extractions.source_text: The resulting LOAD heritability estimate of 24% was based on a sample of 7,139 participants (3,290 cases, 3,849 controls) that included both elderly screened and population controls [71,72].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD)
extractions.method_detail: Ridge et al. (2013) GCTA estimate using ADGC dataset (imputed HapMap phase II)
extractions.source_text: Concurrent ly, Ridge et al. (2013) leveraged the Alzheimer’s Disease Genetics Consortium (ADGC) dataset [73], including 10,922 individuals (5,708 cases, 5,214 controls), and estimated a higher heritab

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD)
extractions.method_detail: 2016 ADGC update using GCTA/GREML (required non-missing data across 21 known AD genes)
extractions.source_text: A 2016 update included data from 30 studies within the ADGC, and the heritability estimate increased to 53%. This study included only 9,699 individuals (3,877 cases, 5,822 controls) [75].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — age >80
extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) age-stratified GCTA estimates (unrelated individuals)
extractions.source_text: Lo et al (2019) with a much larger sample size of unrelated individuals estimated a higher heritability for participants >80 years of age (n = 5,198; h2 = 24.1%) compared with those aged 60–69 years o

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — age 60–69
extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) age-stratified GCTA estimates (unrelated individuals)
extractions.source_text: Lo et al (2019) with a much larger sample size of unrelated individuals estimated a higher heritability for participants >80 years of age (n = 5,198; h2 = 24.1%) compared with those aged 60–69 years o

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — women
extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) sex-stratified GCTA estimates (reported alongside age-strata)
extractions.source_text: Differences by sex were subtler with a slightly higher LOAD heritability among women (21.5%) compared with men (19.5%) [78].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — men
extractions.method_detail: Lo et al. (2019) sex-stratified GCTA estimates
extractions.source_text: Differences by sex were subtler with a slightly higher LOAD heritability among women (21.5%) compared with men (19.5%) [78].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD)
extractions.method_detail: Wang et al. (2021) GCTA on 2-phase ADGC data incorporating cohort indicators
extractions.source_text: Wang et al. (2021) similarly incorporated cohort indicators in their analysis of 2-phase ADGC data, obtaining an expected comparable heritability estimate of 21% [78].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — histopathologically confirmed cases (cohort range)
extractions.method_detail: Baker et al. (2023) GCTA-style estimates applying a consistent model with a 5% liability threshold across five cohorts; this value is the lower end of reported range (31%–57%) for histopath-confirmed cases
extractions.source_text: Baker et al (2023) illustrated this by demonstrating that the histopathologically confirmed LOAD yielded higher heritability estimates (31% - 57%) compared to clinically diagnosed LOAD (12% - 32%) whe

extractions.source_text: Baker et al (2023) illustrated this by demonstrating that the histopathologically confirmed LOAD yielded higher heritability estimates (31% - 57%) compared to clinically diagnosed LOAD (12% - 32%) whe

extractions.trait: APOE (component of LOAD heritability)
extractions.method_detail: Reported APOE-specific contribution to LOAD heritability (lowest reported, proxy SNPs for APOE) across SNP-based studies
extractions.source_text: APOE explains a substantial portion of the genetic risk for LOAD. The lowest heritability estimate (4%) was obtained using proxy SNPs for APOE [72].

extractions.trait: APOE (component of LOAD heritability)
extractions.method_detail: Reported APOE-specific contribution to LOAD heritability (highest reported across cited studies)
extractions.source_text: APOE has an outsized effect and alone contributes substantially to LOAD heritability, accounting for an estimated 4% to 13.42% of the total phenotypic variance (Fig 3) [72,74–76,78].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — LDSC observed-scale (Zheng et al. 2017)
extractions.method_detail: Zheng et al. (2017) LDSC observed-scale estimate (based on relevant GWAS summary statistics)
extractions.source_text: Zheng et al. (2017) and Chen et al. (2021) reported similar observed-scale heritability estimates of 6.88% and 6.80%, respectively [87,89].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — LDSC observed-scale (Chen et al. 2021)
extractions.method_detail: Chen et al. (2021) LDSC observed-scale estimate (reported similar to Zheng et al. 2017)
extractions.source_text: Zheng et al. (2017) and Chen et al. (2021) reported similar observed-scale heritability estimates of 6.88% and 6.80%, respectively [87,89].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — LDSC liability-scale (Brainstorm Consortium 2018)
extractions.method_detail: Brainstorm Consortium (2018) LDSC liability-scale estimate using population prevalence = 17%
extractions.source_text: In contrast, the Brainstorm Consortium et al. (2018) provided a markedly different liability-scale heritability estimate of 13%, using a population prevalence of 17% for the transformation [88].

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — LDSC (Wightman et al. 2021)
extractions.method_detail: Wightman et al. (2021) large GWAS (sample: 761,702) produced an LDSC heritability estimate referenced in the review as the low end (3.1%)
extractions.source_text: Wightman et al. (2021) further expanded the scope of LOAD genetic research by including additional cohorts ... resulting in a sample size of 761,702 (43,725 cases, 717,979 controls) and its own herita

extractions.trait: late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) — LDSC re-evaluation (range from study [97])
extractions.method_detail: Re-evaluation reported LDSC-based LOAD heritability range 9%–17% (lower bound entry from re-evaluation [97], prevalence used = 5%)
extractions.source_text: the LOAD heritability estimates using LDSC ranged from 9% to 17% [97] ... with a consistent population prevalence of 5%
